Brian Button wrote:
>What we did, and as I recommend to my clients, is to separate out the
>plumbing logic (the MIDlet) from the business logic. Have the MIDlet
>create and call the business logic, but keep that creation logic
>really simple. Put all the complexity into the business logic classes,
>which are a lot easier to test.

But, why use j2meUnit then? if you test only the "non midp specific" logic
you can also relay on JUnit.
I found it very easy to modify the test suit to run as midlet on an
emulator, now you can use the textui to assert RMS operations etc.

I recommend to invoke testsuites from midlets added to your suite, on deploy
you can easly remove them.

regards roland kofler

>>>>> "Don" == don quixada <don_quixada> writes:

Hi, Don,

Sorry I never got back to you. I wonder if your problem is directly
creating the MIDlet in your test code. MIDlets are like applets --
they expect a lot of other stuff to be in place when they are
created. It is possible that directly creating them, as you did, just
won't work without the rest of that context.

What we did, and as I recommend to my clients, is to separate out the
plumbing logic (the MIDlet) from the business logic. Have the MIDlet
create and call the business logic, but keep that creation logic
really simple. Put all the complexity into the business logic classes,
which are a lot easier to test.

    Don> I'd really like to get the textui testrunner working for j2me
    Don> unit-- let me know how.

Once I split out the business logic, J2MEUnit just worked for us. This
includes the text version as well as the GUI version. Can you test the
non-MIDlet logic through J2MEUnit?
